>>6486594
a number of things.
>A character's hidden nature is revealed when put under pressure (like real people, character's nature can be contradictory, but in a story something should motivate that behavior)
>Dialogue doesn't have to be like real life, in fact it's better if it isn't. Dialogue should advance the plot or reveal characters. (this is a mistake I often made)
>Keep dialogue in short sentences whenever possible.
>Contradictory behavior adds multiple dimensions to characters, otherwise characters are dull.
>A story only moves ahead through conflict
>If narration is used, use it to convey ironies and insights of a character, not to describe something that can be easily described visually.
>Find your character's deepest desires and fears (often they're not fully aware of them).
>Better if we know a character better than he knows himself.
>Think of the story climax, and work backwards.
>McKee describes structure of the story, how to make an outline. Traditional structures can be broken, but only if writer has a good reason to do so.
That's just 10. The book is packed full of substance. McKee is not dogmatic, 'rules' can be broken if the story calls for it.

No, I got them off cgpeers. I am the same chud btw. desu, the lesson are good but.. at the same time I feel you are kinda better off studying off Michael Hampton and Goldfingers anatomy book.

I haven't fully made my mind on it. Will Weston seems great to remind you of Composition rules, since its a mix of Peter Han/Krenz in the sense that perspective is approched in a more artistic way, but I also felt that after 2 weeks of studying Will Weston's figure drawing, I didn't really understand muscles and how they connect to the bones, which is something I literally learned in just 2 days of Michael Hampton due to the way he properly goes in depth into the topic.

I guess... Will Weston is good for getting a general vibe for the figure, simplified forms, concpts of simple/complex, overlap, 1/2/3 reads for cubes..
But Michael Hampton also touches on that too, and seems more indepth..

Maybe try both and make your own mind, I can't really decide rn

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483868
india ink can be a lot of different products. some have no binder, some have gelatin glue as binder with the lamp black in colloidal suspension, some have shellac as binder in a weak alkaline solution, and maybe some even are based on whatever dye. the ones pigments can stay without binder because the particles are very small or also because the particles have some tarry residue. they are usually waterproof or claim to when dry but often not completely. i don't see why in the case of gelatin or shellac binder since gelatin dissolves with enough moisture and warmth, while alkaline salts remain after the water evaporates.
acrylic ink is more waterproof when dry. it can dissolve with alcohol.
you might see more differences if you use them with other media.

posts.com:
>>6483080
You can work out foreshortening using a geometrical method called parallel projection. It entails first drawing a simple view, then projecting parallel lines from various points on the figure at a desired angle to construct a second view. Sometimes, as in picrel, one or more intermediary steps are required to get the desired end result. Picrel is from Jean Cousin's Livre de Portraiture, which contains many examples. You can also find a few simple (one-step) examples of this method in Burne Hogarthe's Dynamic Figure Drawing. It shows up mostly in older books, though.
Note: This method does not give you size/camera distortion, only foreshortening. For the former, you need to set up a picture plane and have your projecting lines converge towards a point representing the eye of the viewer.
This is all fascinating but I don't recommend it. When it takes more than one step, it's an enormous amount of labor; furthermore, it's difficult to predict the end result. It is better to work intuitively and train your eye to what looks right. If you insist on perfect accuracy, using a 3D model as the basis for your drawing would achieve the same result and save you a lot of time.

>>6483080
>I know there's a scientific mathe formula

well if you really want to torture yourself...

Bruce MacEvoy's Handprint has one of the most comprehensive explanations of perspective anywhere on the web:
https://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/tech10.html#index

Wade Meyers is an aviation artist who uses descriptive geometry for all of his aircraft drawings & renderings. 2d plan drawings are required to construct objects this way. You also have to already understand the basic mathematics of perspective in the previous link to understand anything he's saying:
https://www.wademeyersstudios.com/book/1774/perspective-projection-by-descriptive-geometry-a-manual-for-the-artist
There are other introductions to descriptive geometry but this one is made for aviation and vehicle artists specifically.

Willy A. Bartschi's "Linear Perspective" book gives you an history of linear perspective, its applications, and also the "circle of view" method.
https://archive.org/details/linearperspectiv0000bart/mode/2up
I think this is the best introduction to formal perspective.

But like everyone else in this thread is saying, technical perspective is going to give you a headache if all you want to do is construct foreshortened figures. It would be much easier just to learn the basic freehand perspective that everyone teaches.
This stuff is really only necessary if you want to create technical drawings, drawings with really accurate measurements, industrial design, architecture... etc.. but in those fields descriptive geometry has already been superseded by CAD and 3D software which do all the thinking for you.

>>6484333
No problem. It is good to know these things, because technical perspective applies to more than just 2d art. 3D software runs off of the same mathematical foundation, and photography is a quite literal representation of the projection plane and camera, so the same composition techniques apply.

Like >>6483111 was saying, distortion and foreshortening can be achieved with technical perspective techniques. Remember that you can change your field of view in the same way as you can with a camera.

The "circle of view" method of perspective described by Bartschi is also incorporated in a more digestible form in Scott Robertson's "How to Draw," he calls it "cone of vision" but they're functionally the same thing.
Here's a youtube video that summarizes it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RsbzCHLsQuQ

Regarding "How to Draw," later in the book Robertson decides to only do the tedious method of subdividing squares diagonally over and over again to build forms in perspective. Just doing perspective projection with plan views for complex forms would have been easier. Do that instead for hard-surface shit.

I don't think people are "hiding" any secret technique on how to foreshorten. Art education in technical perspective collapsed after abstract art, and then descriptive geometry suffered a massive blow when CAD and 3D software phased it out of higher education (Back in the day architecture schools had professors solely dedicated to teaching descriptive geometry).

Most people are only capable of teaching lazy methods of foreshortening because that's all they've ever known, and without any accessible knowledge on the subject people just brute-force their way into it, iterating over and over again until their perspective or foreshortening looks sound. And because they've never been taught any technical knowledge, they have no vocabulary to describe what they're doing, so most "tutorials" just boil down to
>yeah just uh make it bigger when its closer

>>6487536
Not commenting on his work (not familiar with it). But from this tutorial, I can tell you he is needlessly overcomplicating the subject, and also presenting questionable "facts," such as there being "6 vanishing points in total." In fact, any set of parallel lines that inclines away from the picture plane will have a vanishing point, and the number of vanishing points will depend on how many such sets of lines are inclined at angles different from all the others. The vanishing points could be on the horizon line, above or below it. You could have hundreds or thousands of vanishing points in a single image (imagine a disorganized heap of Legos, each with its own sets of vanishing points).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6486547
Prior to 3D modeling being widely available, if you wanted to (for example) create game assets from an oblique overhead view, this geometric method would allow you to set a viewing angle (say, 60 degrees) in relation to the ground plane, and construct all your frames of character animation, as well as objects and scenery, and have everything be consistently foreshortened throughout. Part of the reason I'm familiar with this stuff is because I once tried it as an experiment, animating a character in 8 directions with an idle stance and 6-frame run cycle. It is extremely labor intensive but it does work. With human figures, there is still a lot of artistic intuition involved. The geometry will give you different points but a human body is not a rectangular prism; you still have to draw it yourself.
I guess what I'm saying is, some types of drawing have the requirements of both art and math, as in my game example, wherein it was necessary to maintain consistency among multiple frames of animation/directions of movement in difficult foreshortening. But using this method for regular illustration would be counterproductive and would suck the life out of your drawing.

The goal for Guilty Gear animations is to mimic hand-drawn 2d anime, down to the imperfections. All the frames are hand crafted poses and parts are often tweaked and distorted per frame. If they'd just slapped on a distorting lens and not destroyed the figure it wouldn't look nearly as convincing and comes across as quite stiff.

That's kind of the benefit of not sticking to a really strict formula, even when just drawing. "Winging it" requires some form of understanding of perspective but then deciding to break those rules or to say "fuck it" if the result is way more dynamic and appealing.

>>6482660
Western animation used to barely use shading. Ever since shit like Megas and Boondocks they realized "oh fuck we can add shading like the jappos???" and now you have this thing where the jaunty, constrained "action show" western syle of making things actually move is blended with that style of cel shading and it looks really fucking bad.
Like there's no flow to it, you see it with all the netflix crap because it's a lazy way for them to add depth to otherwise stiff poses and actions.

A TRUE "western-anime" would be like the OG CN Teen Titans or The Boondocks. Avatar is a few layers removed from those but I'll count it as it's closer, I guess.

Funnily enough though, a lot of anime from the past decade moved to using LESS shading, either going with more of a flat style or just keeping it subtle. I'm not sure if some of that is to mesh with the use of 3D models cleaner or just a stylistic choice, but it still looks good and really emphasizes how the actual movements and flow are better than things like that anon posted.

posts.name: Anonymous

The MOST timesaving thing for a comic is skillful layout and planning to shove all the budget into a few choice panels people remember, while minimizing the work you need to do in the less-important ones.
Same way Berserk was drawn when it was regular. Most panels are designed to be made FAST and errors are accepted if they're within tolerance, it's the big shots that have all the effort put in.

Also having assistants, using premade assets, tracing, etc all help.

No, the teacher of the superstar artist isn't considered influential just because the superstar artist is highly successful. Especially if the teacher is mostly unknown otherwise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6486204
You're conflating teaching with influence. If a teacher's student becomes successful off their learnings, then yeah they totally do get to say that they TAUGHT that successful person. INFLUENCED is a different concept.
No, somebody who made something unsuccessful doesn't get to claim responsibility for the success of a future work that is influenced by it, because they played no part in assisting the successful person. Nobody said that they should be able to "claim credit", nor did anybody imply it, so I don't see why you jumped to that conclusion.
And being able to claim credit or not is irrelevant to the influence this person's work had on the successful work, and neither is whether or not the influential work was successful. The concept of "influence" is an objective one. Person A makes Work A, Person B sees Work A and says "That's cool, I like the way x and y" and goes on to make Work B, with x and y. Factually speaking, Work B was influenced by Work A. Person A can be cool with it, or want to claim at least partial credit for x and y, and Person B may or may not acknowledge it and give credit, none of this actually matters toward whether or not Work A influenced Work B.

>>6487684
Limit your free time. Every moment that you can work on your craft the sooner you get to your goal.
That means story writing, scripts, character creating, storyboards. You dont have to have all of it super flushed out before you start but it helps. Start with shorter series first so you can really iron out common mistakes before taking on epics.
Making it is a different thing, sometimes certain stories take a while to build up popularity and very few explode over night. Youre looking at least a year or more to really start pulling in readers, let alone the ones that are willing to pay.
Once you get enough readers put next weeks/months chapters behind pay wall.

>>6487684
How to do it?
1. Be able to create at least 22 pages of good artwork per month
2. Be good at writing and drawing, writing being more important
3. Create a webcomic and establish an audience and proven record
4. Once you have an audience and a proven record hire an agent

If you can do all of that and you don't suck, plus a little luck then you'll probably be able to make a living, your agent can push the other side of things with publishers. Publishers will be apprehensive about a no-name artist, that's why establishing an audience beforehand will help you greatly, they'd rather publish scribbles by some movie star creating a comic as his side project than good work from some nobody.

Making a living with comics is more difficult now than it's ever been before. The industry itself has been on a decline ever since the bubble popped in the 90's.

The internet is also double edged sword. Yes you can finally self-publish but so can everyone else. Now the web is oversaturated with webcomics. I've seen guys that are dedicated and spend years making comics and don't even make close to what you'd make flipping burgers or they create a large volume of work and nobody cares.

>>6478013
I am also a late starter. I started at the age of 29 and even went to art school after. The difficulties are mostly psychological in nature. I was already established in my field, made good money and was regarded as a high achiever in things that required a logic/math oriented mind. Starting out people chuckled at my trash art, they saw it in contrast to my wagie achievements and also even felt safe to shit talk me, because "I could take it right?".
Things got worse when I went to art school to try to become pro at some point. The school itself was great, and I didnt mind meeting younger people better than me, it was actually a blast. The bad part are family, partners, friends who actively discourage you "from throwing your life and talent away". This continues to this day, I am 36 now and a decent artist. Yes I don't earn nearly as much as I did, but I am happy and don't feel depressed anymore. Still get offers from people in STEM "to come work" with them. It's meant well, but I can't help but feel hurt by the fact that the people closest to me think what I am doing is kind of a joke and they are still waiting for me to "snap out of it" and get a real job.
Just be prepared to find new art friends and be humble again. You will go from high regarded normie to nobody overnight. You will most likely not get support from the people you think who would, even worse you will get discouragement throughout. This, paired with the fact that you will have low confidence at first (because you are bad and even young kids are better than you) makes it incredibly hard to make it. Good thing is, it's all in your head, it's a psychological challenge, the neuroplasticity crap is bullshit, I caught up to everyone quickly.

>>6479322
I will tell from my expirience. I've been drawing since childhood. Didn't go in artscool or art classes. I drew cartoons, anime, some of my fantasies. My classmates thought that I was good at drawing, my parents also praised me. I thought I was good, when in reality I just drew like a child who loves to draw. In each class there are at least 1-2 such children. You know these guys, or maybe you were them.
With age, I began to draw less and less, by the age of 18-19 I drew maybe a couple of times a year.
But one time I needed to draw pictures for my text rpg, and god, I realized how shitty of this i was.
This caused me great pain, never in my life i hated and despised myself more.
So I took courses in academic drawing and painting. I was 27 at the time.
Now I'm 31 and I still continue my education. By no means do I claim that I am a good artist now, I am not even close, but I see my growth with each work.

So, in my opinion, drawing as a child gives only two good things:
1. Fine motor skills develop.
2. You go through the drawing phase for fun as a teenager.

The first catches up very quickly, in just a couple of lessons you will already be good friends with a pencil/stylus.

The second point is what breaks many adult beginners.

The realization that before you start drawing your fantasies, you have to go through the hard and boring part. And it may take years. Those who have been drawing since childhood already had their fun. They have drawn cute anime girls, robots, disney princesses and monsters.They understand that it will not get better. And they will have to suffer. And accept it more humbly.

All this, of course, does not apply to those who studied in art schools as children, and then continued their studies in art at a college or university. These guys are gods and we will never catch up with them.

>>6481180
It doesn't stagnate, rather it forces us to face a different reality, which in turn changes how we do things and what we make.
Using AI vs not using AI is a deliberate choice now, whereas art in the previous paradigm had none. The simple act of someone declining to use (or choosing to use) AI directly in their art says something - however WHAT it says is dependent on the context around that person. In my case, for example, I just detest the process of painting. So AI has almost no use for me beyond references, ideas, and similar indirect usage.

It's like how images of real things can be photographed or made by hand. The choice to use a machine to take a picture is what many people do, but landscape artists (painters, illustrators and more) still do what they do. Digital vs trad also is a similar situation.

My gut tells me that a lot of artists feel like old school draftsmen when CAD took over, but I really don't think this is the case - they're just suffering brainrot from immersing themselves in demoralizing, misanthropic, propagandistic takes about humanity on the regular. So when this came around it was like lighting that angst-fuel on fire.

>>6487579
Drawing hot girls was literally what revived my motivation. From there I got decent at figures which resulted in more motivation for "normal stuff". The days were I gave up on "drawing seriously" I ended up studying the most anatomy and construction. For example I a phase were I was obsessed with sexy legs and feet, sketched hundreds of them on Pinterest, but then felt an overwhelming curiousity to understand knees better. Funmaxxing is seriously underrated and might be one of the bigger reasons why kids get good fast. They just care about the fun and as adults we tend to forget that. Even if your ambitions are serious, spend most of your time on shit that's fun. Just keep in mind that most ref as terrible lighting, but instead of being selective, it's better to draw everything that attracts you, but keep the rendering to a minimum or don't render at all.

>>6476156
I've been a professional illustrator for 20 years now.
I used Photoshop for around 10 years for my work. Besides that I only tried other software for fun (Painter, PaintToolSAI, etc.).
When I started to work on some comics related projects I decided to try CSP (Still called Manga Studio at the time), because a few art friends said it had nice tools for drawing line-art.
It was love at first sight, because of it's pencils/inks brush engine and the feel of the brushes. CSP has the ability to use your stroke speed as a line thickness modifier and it allowes me to rotate my canvas (photoshop introduced that feature later on but it's crap to this day), which at the time was a game changer for me (check pic attached). Photoshop simply couldn't compete anymore for natural/traditional looking line-art.
At first I still used Photoshop for coloring and painting my line drawings, but then I completely moved away from it and fully switched to CSP.

CSP pros (vs Photoshop):
- much better line art brushes and engine
- canvas rotation (photoshop with his inertia thing is total crap)
- better color mixing brushes
- better perspective and ruler tools (out of the box at least)
- more stable (I haven't used Photoshop seriously in almost a decade, so this might have changed)
- cheaper

CSP cons (vs Photoshop):
- doesn't support modern multi core processors (when I switched to CSP back in the day, this wasn't an issue, since Photoshop was a resources consuming always crashing mess)
- more limited for custom brushes that involve painting

>>6476156
Long text well about my experiences with PS vs CSP
If you're new to digital art, I would still learn this first as this will force you to learn the brush system and all the basics. If you know Photoshop, you know everything. You can literally get hired at lots of places for just being able to show you can use Photoshop well.
People say that CSP runs faster but I don't think this is true. Unoptimized CSP runs faster, but if you just google "Photoshop 60 fps" "Making Photoshop Faster" from Borodante or KNKL you'll find that Photoshop can fully utilize multithreaded machine setups. Even with higher end PC builds, I've noticed Photoshop runs faster than CSP, even after tweaking settings for both. For some reason the cursor on Photoshop just tracks directly behind your pen much more accurately than CSP by a tiny margin, whereas CSP you have to do extensive fuckery to get that to be the close to the same.
For CSP The Pen pressure is more customizable meaning I have more options for line brushes and adjusting things. This is not as big of an advantage as you'd think though as for PS the Pen pressure control out of the box works great already, whereas in CSP you usually have to fuck around for a bit to get it feel right. Usually I end up changing all my pens to a straight or slight curve and make everything dependent on my tablet curve pressure anyway.
I still use CSP mainly for 2 reasons:
The program is constantly getting better and better, whereas the newer versions of Photoshop is actually getting worse than CS6 for painting artwork. With the future updates, it will surpass PS
CSP EX has a built in storyboarding feature that is extremely valuable for organizing and making a workflow for making manga/comics and an industry level animation timeline workflow. I've only ever dabbled in those, but I like the feeling that if I ever wanted to make personal projects CSP already has me covered.

because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)

>>6444534
I'm assuming these are all from same person yeah?
I'd suggest more decisive lines, try to visualize what you want to put down before you do. Looks like you're familiar with drawthrough method obviously, but yeah there is some inconsistencies in the perspective, but the drawings major issue is the hairy lines, also once you have that down don't get lost in the details, make sure it still reads as the object intended from a distance. You could also try drawing some mechanical objects in a 3 point perspective and see how you do. Hope that helps although You've probably heard similar advice before

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6458574
I was toying around with threads and I got it to look decent, though the perspective is off.
As for the texture, I made Triangle pattern and used the bend tool or w/e in Kirta since I was trying to see how it would look, trying to go for that camo netting pattern thats pretty hard to draw, In the end it was just a test, since I was learning about using textures and what not.
The hard part about the treads is that it it looks off if the perspective is off. It took me a bit to figure out how shade these and show that they are treads on the track, but you need a good underline or if not, dont strictly follow the underline if you know the perspective is off. I could fix it but I moved on for this until I get some coloring practice in.

I felt stupid after I spent so much time putting together that imagine and re-read your request. You can get a script to do it with Tampermonkey, too; the disadvantage of these methods is that you're still up against a limit of how many pictures you're allowed to access in a given period of time. This limit regenerates pretty quickly, but not *that* fast. Like I said in >>6462087, there are books and collections on there worth many thousands of Gallery Points, and you'd hit your limit pretty quickly downloading those via script - anyone would.

On the plus side, it still doesn't cost any money to use a script ... so there is that.

as somone who just started learning the figure using both proko and vilppu simultaneously, it's astounding how different proko's approach to gesture is than vilppus.

Proko constantly says "MOTION NOT CONTOUR" but all his demo videos are him simplifying contours.... then you look at vilppu and you see him making these fluid lines that actually seem related to motion and realize how stiff proko's shit is

desu tho, proko's gesture is much easier for a beg to learn. I still really struggle to do gesture in the same manner as vilppu and this is my third week grinding it.

Disney animator Glen Keane claims to have aphantasia. Do you think he, and other artists like him, have true aphantasia? I can certainly imagine that purely observational artists could draw well with aphantasia (in fact I could even see the lack of distraction from mental images to be helpful in this pursuit), but I don't quite get how an artist with true aphantasia could even begin a drawing from imagination. I saw him say that he starts with scribbles and refines from there, but starting with a rough gesture and refining is common practice even for artists who can see images in their mind, and I'd think a true lack of mental imaging would prohibit the placement of even a comprehensible gestural sketch from imagination.

tl;dr Do creative artists with aphantasia truly exist, or are they just full of shit/don't actually have thoughts devoid of imagery?

Hello, I hope I am not being obnoxious talking about my girlfriend again. But she has true Aphantasia (Cannot see any kind of visual memories in her mind at all).
However, she began drawing around 3 weeks ago and I am training her using a similar path to what Krenz proposes.
So far, I am seeing her progress faster than i did (I stand in stark contrast, as I am I can visualize very well).
Things I've noticed she seems naturally better at.
1.Organizing her process, from the steps on going from sketch to coloring to layer organization
2. She seems to have a better hand to eye coordination, has a lot of patience and works well.
3. Takes a lot more care in detailing, fishing, making something presentable
4. She is able to notice details in things that often go over me, as I am often lost in thought, that comes both for observation and general media consumption

I am curious to see her progress, and I'll likely post more about how effective the training is for anyone else with Aphantasia or who might simply be curious.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6475582
Most of us are just executing a procedure here and there trying to bend it toward "what looks good" with trial and error. Sometimes we have a strong idea and try to bend it toward that, but that makes the process harder.

I don't have aphantasia, but I don't have strong visualization abilities, and making visualizations isn't part of my or most other artists process.

I think you have some idealized notion that artists "see something in their mind" and mentally project it onto a page and trace. I'd be surprised if even one human artist on the whole planet does that.

There are artist that *do* have visualization as part of their process, like the late Kim Jung Gi, but another part of the process was building a library of processes by doing drawings from reference of lots of different things.

Draftsman, animators and painters from imagination don't have psychic powers. They just work harder than you and know more than you.

interesting topic. as someone visiting from /x/ I think I have a vague grasp on aphantasia. someone explained it like having a PC running, processing images and all kinds of visuals but then having no monitor connected to that PC. so you know what's going on, you just can't see it on the screen. that fits my situation as well. I do have a memory, I know what I look like or my mother. I just can't project it into my visual field or use my third eye to see it with my mind's eye. I have a friend of mine who can project anything into his sight, we call that hyperphantasia. btw I do have imagination since my "PC is working well". It's different for audio stuff tho. I can hear my thoughts in any voice, imagine music and instruments, sounds and stuff in my head. other senses like smell, touch and taste are less pronounced. I can feel imagined touch to some degree but taste and smell are basically not existent. I do differentiate between the third eye visualization, hypnagogia and dreams. I do dream and I see them just the same as if I'm awake. I do see flashes when tired and shortly before going to sleep. for me that's working alright. but in the waking state I just see black when closing my eyes, I just see black when thinking of a person or an object. I know the underlying concept of it though and memorized the most important details on my mental HDD.

as another anon said here, drawing for me is like starting out on a blank space, knowing what do to in theory, but going in completely blind, building up with each stroke, trial and error, not knowing where the actual drawing goes on paper.

btw some people claim they don't think in words but concepts. also some people can not read a book without moving their mouth to speak the words, because they can't think them in their head. this entire aphantasia thing is to me is so much more than just a lack of visualization. it's the understanding of the workings of our human minds in infinite complexity

I'd imagine for most people with good visualization, the memory aspect still operates just like any other memory. The famous "apple scale" could apply even for people with good visual memory - never seen a thing means nothing comes to mind, seen it a time or two and paid attention to it means you can conjure a hazy image, paid rather close attention with some comprehension and you can see a clear-ish image, see it a lot and are familiar with it and you can kinda play around with it in your head. There's other aspects, too, like somebody with decent visualization can mesh memories together while looking at things, like looking at a character, then using their memory of anatomy, come up with a visualization of the character in a certain pose in their mind. As you said, it doesn't mean it will be correct, but there is a meaningful image in their head that can be translated to the page for further refinement.

>>6475582
As a person with Aphantasia, you're being silly. You misunderstand how the brain works. Visual memory operates outside of the context of mental imagery. "Mental imagery" is just the experience of visualizing something (people with Aphantasia have this, but with 0 vividness). But, mental imagery is really just a meaningless fart of consciousness. The brain's true mental processes are always subconscious and outside of our own awareness. Drawing also makes use of procedural information and habits, so it would be wrong to think just about visual memory.

Sometimes when I draw I wonder why it is that I draw so much better now than I used to years ago. Why is this possible? Of course, I trained and made art, but it's not like when I'm drawing now that I'm conscious of doing anything that special. The drawings I can make effortlessly now are exponentially better. The only obvious answer is that drawing is far more a subconscious activity than a conscious process (rather, everything is). The brain dredges up shit you're no longer conscious of, and doesn't even bother to tell you. Your brain jumps through all sorts of hoops for you.

Aphantasia makes no real difference on the capacity to draw. In reality, everybody starts out so ass. So ass that I cringe at the thought of trying to bring someone all the way from /beg/ into advanced. If you're a beginner or even int, you still don't quite understand just how deep your own suckiness goes. If you compare yourself to some other beginner improving faster than you, you might think "wow, that's unfair" but you're still both improving at such a snails space and making so many mistakes with how you think about things that it's painful to watch. If I truly understood just how bad I was and how much I was lacking I would have quit in horror. Aphantasia is nothing. The nature of an expert artist's mind/brain is fundamentally the same regardless of who it is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6490258
I have. Don't bother. It's just not the right way of thinking about things. You want to actually use the things you learn in natural contexts in the days after learning something. That's natural spaced repetition. And it should be in natural contexts, like you doing a sketching session to relax a bit or to create art pieces or character designs/etc. An issue with Anki is that the learning stays within a strict context. What you learn needs to pour out like a gushing faucet into other art activities. Otherwise it's still a drag to think about what you've learned.

Furthermore, the encoding process is the key thing here, and doing it right makes it easy to think back to an image you studied and recall information stored related to it. You don't need to use a spaced repetition algorithm to make spacing happen. You want to process an image so deeply that it would be almost impossible for you to not think about it again.

The encoding process I recommend requires high cognitive load and meaningful analysis of an image. Cognitive load is essentially how much brain power you're utilizing. When a lot of brain power is used to manipulate and process information (including images) in a meaningful way (germane cognitive load), robust useful memories are formed in long-term memory.

This has always been the key to building visual library. Everything that works in efficiently building visual library always uses high germane cognitive load. When people do studies for a work they're making, or think it's important to make art pieces from what you study, the reality is that it works because it leads to meaningful processing and high cognitive load going to the right things.

Going further, you want to start with going overkill on a single image study to get a feel for the effects. Memories always pail in comparison to the real experience; they are thinner and more rough. That's why you start with going overboard. Read more here: https://pastebin.com/wQYxGbDp

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6490327
(cont.) It's just my personal opinion but you want to have fewer, more robust memories in your visual library rather than many weak, shallow memories. I understand the desire to want to be able to draw a lot of different things from memory, but it's not that important and trying to do too much too fast will just make them flake away. You may have other fundamentals to be working on, or have artwork to make. Those things will take time to come up, too. You have time to build your visual library. Going slow and deep, to the point that you'd have no reason to use an SRS, is my advice.

>>6489992
Because creativity is domain-specific, and in every domain it boils down to a bunch of design methods. To be creative is to know those methods and how to apply them. For example, if one wants to learn how to design sings, he can read Adrian Frutiger, Andrew Bluhm, Signs and Symbols: Their Design and Meaning, or something like this. Currently, the most developed design methods are for engineering, there are literally hundreds of them (e. g. W. Ernst Eder, Stanislav Hosnedl, Design Engineering: A Manual for Enhanced Creativity, chapter 8).

Also there's a lot of scientific theory, but it's not very useful.
Rex E. Jung, Oshin Vartanian, The Cambridge Handbook of the Neuroscience of Creativity.
Sawyer, Robert Keith, Explaining creativity: the science of human innovation.
https://www.tandfonline.com/toc/hcrj20/current
https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/journal-of-creativity

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6489992
There are some, but most focus on finding ways to quickly iterate ideas. Let me see if I can recall... Basically the creative process is

1) Inspiration - Gathering ideas by having new experiences, meeting new people, watching / reading / playing media. You can actively seek to do research or just open yourself up to new experiences. Having a notebook on you to quickly write (or draw) down thoughts and ideas comes in handy. Try to keep an open mind, not every idea will be a banger, but we're not judging them yet.

2) Iteration - Take some of the ideas you gathered that seem interesting to you. Try to combine them. Try to elaborate on them. Experiment, keep it loose. Come up with one or several outlines, concepts, designs, etc based on your research.

3) Incubation - Let it sit. Really, just do some other projects for a week or two. Take some walks. A hot shower. Meet friends. Give the ideas some space to breathe, a lot will fall into place. Why is this important? While actively thinking to improve something we're forming our expectations and limitations - this is crucial to convert the abstract into something tangible but it's also limiting. It makes us restrained. Purposefully distancing yourself from your work can do wonders. Don't actively work on it in this period. You will most likely have it in the back of your mind and some new thoughts may arise that help you figure out the direction you want to go in. Take notes.

4) Evaluation - At this point you should have a pretty good idea what you want to do. This is editing, refining, polishing the idea. Getting feedback, looking at it critically. Judge your work, see how you can improve it. Rinse and repeat.

The truth is - creativity works different for everyone. Find out what inspires you, what motivates you, what drives you. Get yourself into scenarios that make you want to create, go through the world open minded. Carry around a sketch or notebook. Experiment, experiment, experiment.

>>6490884
NTA but are you arguing that Luca Cambiaso didn't draw?
Drawing figures using boxes and other geometric solids is called stereometry. Cambiaso made loose stereometric studies to help work out the lighting in his paintings.
Albrecht Durer experimented with stereometry quite a bit. He also did tons of proportional diagrams. Ultimately, in contrast to Cambiaso's practical application of stereometry, Durer's seems to have been what /ic/ calls "autistic" behavior, as in obsessing over things that don't yield much value to the process of making actual drawings and paintings.
There is no evidence to suggest that most Renaissance artists employed stereometry in their work. A few of them experimented with it. But it is clear that all of the old masters thought in terms of what Robert Beverly Hale calls "mass conceptions" -- that is, they conceived of forms in the figure as ovoid, cylindrical, boxlike, etc. They drew cross-contour lines in their sketches. This might seem like a distinction without a difference, but the point is that they didn't "autistically" plan out box figures as is suggested by OP's pic (and many YT personalities).
If you want to learn useful stereometry, to aid you in memorizing proportions and learning anatomy, I recommend Roberto Osti's "Basic Human Anatomy." Just don't become one of those people with a box fetish who never actually draws anything but boxes.

whether you draw a box directly or not, you are always obliged, before drawing a body part, to think about the following things, at least subconsciously:
- what is its vertical angle, do we see the top part or the bottom part; and how much?
- what is its horizontal angle, do we see the left part or the right part; and how much?
- what are the proportions?
Basically, you draw or imagine a box. This is an undeniable fact :-)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6488556
"Taste" is, to put it simply, a compound of ideas, concepts and sensory elements one finds attractive or pleasing. Taste is heavily influenced by cultural and psychological factors unique to every subject.
"Skill" is, to put it simply, a combination of physical and mental knowledge applied to the methodical procedures of an action. Skill, while ambiguously measureable in a general sense, can be objectively measured when deconstructed to the specifics and under explicit and strict guidelines for accurate comparison.

With that out of the way, this argument can be broken quite easily:
>Taste has nothing to do with Skill
This is not a matter of "Objective vs Subjective", it's literally comparing oranges to apples; Taste, the emotional and mental gallery of attraction, doesnt relate to Skill, the physical and mental strength of action. One could argue "good Taste makes you highly Skilled" but this is completely false.
Aside from "Good Taste" being false due to it's subjective nature, Taste is not the driving force to higher Skills to begin with, it is Knowledge. One with Taste alone will not understand their craft if they dont seek Knowledge from all it's possible corners.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want to surround yourself with a large community albeit of beginners then Drawabox is fine but it wouldn't be my first choice. ArtWOD or the new NMA discord lessons Dynamic Sketching with Charles Hu would be. Granted I'm recommending these based on the fact you have some experience. If you're the type of person that sees better artwork by fellow students and gets discouraged then I wouldn't bother with these.
If you're ok with no feedback you have Sorie Kim's course on Class101 or even Foundation Groups lessons.

>or do you have any other alternatives?
Peter Han's course on Dynamic Sketching. Scott Robertson's How to Draw. These are the works DaB bases their exercises around.

Will doing DaB hurt? Probably not. But it's the dryest shit ever and lacks both the more free form life drawing approach of Han, as well as the almost architectural technical knowledge of Robertson. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456218
I had a similar issue and it might sound retarded but try going the exact opposite direction and take some time aside to do whatever you think would be the most miserable, unfun exercise. For me that was copying a Bargue plate. By the end of it you won't have burst into flames and even if it takes way longer than it should've or looks horrible it's not the end of the world and you'll have gotten something out of the experience.
After doing that I became progressively more ok with the idea of doing studies even though I used to be super averse to the very idea of drawing copies since you're going through all that trouble just to reproduce something that's already there. I understood the value theoretically but had no fucking patience to subject myself to it. Sitting down to study and analyze a picture can actually end up being really fun, specially if it's an artist you like. To me this was unthinkable because the only way I had fun before was making shit up and tossing the drawing as soon as I got bored.
Just pick one thing and stick with it, the more you do it the more used you'll get to it. For me, at least, the problem was that I was too used to drawing mindlessly as recreation so studying felt unnatural and scary. It's just a matter of getting used to something unfamiliar.
Again I know it's retardedly simple but I think it's the most reliable solution. Just be consistent with it and eventually the aversion will be gone. You'll always have plenty of time to draw your own stuff for fun, and it'll expand your options.

Either find what you like drawing, get out of a comfort zone, experiment by fucking with different media/styles, or find something else entirely. Even if you might be good at it, it may still not be a fit because you don't like it. For example I'm great at the physical and mental aspects of my work, but there's so much bureaucratic paperwork horseshit associated that it sucks all joy I might have from it.

Art as a profession is something one should take joy in otherwise while the skill may remain, the soul goes away. Art as something for yourself doesn't need to worry about it, and if you don't enjoy it, much as I hate the word, you're just being a poser for likes and (You)s.

Do what you love anon. Draw what you love, draw who you love

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451437
Practice, simple as.
When I did go to an art school for a bit, I went in expecting to be amongst titans, but I still ended up being a big fish in a small pond, mostly because I've been drawing for longer than most have been alive there.
You just gotta do it over and over again, until eventually you can internalize steps and externally "skip" them, so instead of doing the rough skeleton, your able to go straight to rough details and all of that.
At one point I just went hard mode and exclusively used ball point pen to draw, so no pencil roughs to erase later, just try to make it look good in one go, results turned out to about pic related.
Just practice practice practice

posts.com: how do you "push the pose" of a reference you're using?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472119
Find the gesture, and exaggerate it. say their torso is bent to the right, and they are in sort of a ( shape, exaggerate that, push their hips more to the left, and the top torso to the right. Don't push it pas the point of being goofy and making a C shape, but you get the idea. If you watch any of the pros do gesture, you'll notice immediately.

posts.com:
I think I might be too dumb to learn perspective.
I'm practicing perspective to learn to draw scenarios according to Dong Ho Kim's Space Drawing Perspective book, at some point it tells us to practice with real photographs and try to identify the vanishing points and practice drawing it.
Easy enough, I can put the vanishing points at eye level and sketch the general scenario, but when I'm trying to add detail, I realize that there are objects in the scenario that don't fit the existing vanishing points, and rather they seem to have their own, so I must have missed these vanishing points at the beginning, and then I get overwhelmed. Am I inherently retarded, or what am I doing wrong?

For example, picrel, it immediately jumps to me as a one point perspective, squarely centered, that's why I chose it, it was easy, but then look at the chairs on the floor or the bench near the camera, if I try to draw them in this one point perspective they become all wonky, so there's another point I'm missing, so I put another point in the horizon, but now the whole piece has two perspective points, so it must be a two point perspective, but now then the scenario becomes wonky if I try to fit it.
Or is it that there's TWO one point perspectives? How does that happen? Am I overthinking it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6481188
In that picture with the table im sure youll find that theres three points of perspective. Yes there can be more then one and thats our reality. The first perspective you lay down is more or less the bases for the hallway and the other two perspectives are helpful for the furniture. Because furniture does not always align with the first vanishing point
Im still a beg when it comes to perspective myself and the confusion is part of the learning process. I cant find a pic that truly shows what im trying to say but I found one that shows two points indoors. Indoor perspective is tricky.

I'd also learn perspective, design, dive deeper into color and value, and do studies/plein airs to learn more about light and nuance of everything in nature.

First you got to figure out what you want to draw.
Example: If you want to draw a dragon, draw a dragon, if it doesn't come out well then look for references. Then after a few studies try to draw the dragon again with out references.
Then replace dragon with whatever you actually want.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6488939
This. You can't compare panels from a serialized comic book to one-off illustrations that 90% of every piece of art you have seen are. Not only is there a difference between the time limits each type of art are given to be completed, but there is a measured time limit that a person will on average look at of each.

Each panel of a comic is seen for at most a few seconds by a reader, just enough to read any text and understand what is happening in the image, then on to the next. It's absolutely NOT worth spending hours constructing and rendering every fucking panel and page. Despite that, Miura obviously spent more and more time doing exactly that, which contributed to his declining health and irritating his readers with delays.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I read a lot of comics not just manga, mostly Franco-Belgian BDs for the last few years but Berserk is one of the best I've read in terms of storytelling. Not the story or the writing itself, which is more subjective but there's nothing quite as fluid as Berserk in terms of action and panel flow. You're hooked in the first couple of pages and always waiting for those special cinematic moments that only Miura could pull off. This ability has been lost now with the assistants and his good friend Mori, who is also a talented mangaka. He has interesting stuff but it's different so it cannot be replicated, or even, continued.

There are many other great authors but few have this skill and the compelling story and characters. I'm not talking about art. If you go to any European comic store you understand that they have superior artistic standards but well, the stories are more like movies and don't produce the same effect manga does.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6489036
Vagabond is actually average at best. Good art but it's too clinical, too perfect for my taste. And the storytelling is terrible, it goes nowhere and there's no excitement whatsoever for any fights. No substance.

You can compare it to Vinland Saga, both detailed art but clearly too prepared, not fluid enough but at least VS has interesting characters.

Nothing wrong with clean artstyle btw, but the lines must have some sensuality in the curves, some courage. Masters of ligne claire had perfectly accurate line work but they expressed everything with the bare minimum of a single line and contained form.

To a similar extent you have Monkey Punch, who I consider to be one of the best mangakas of all time, a true Master of the line. To a whole different level compared to stuff like Vagabond, but I understand the more rigid and clean style can be more appealing at first, but the taste gets refined with age.

posts.sub: How can I train my creativity?
posts.com:
When I see other artists’ work it’s full of different ideas, concepts, it looks like a flow that doesn’t stop. But when it comes to drawing stuff by myself, I can’t seem to come up with anything good (I don’t have aphantasia). I always end up drawing the same boring and uninteresting stuff over and over.
Is there a way for me to improve my creativity or is it something people are born with?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6490144
consume media, steal ideas from other artists

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The two keys to this is output and experimentation; you have to keep a constant flow of output as well as a restriction that forces you to try different things. Even if it isn't good at first, you'll start to run into problems and figure out solutions to them over time until you have a good grasp on an effective creative process. Some of those inktober prompt lists can be a decent starting point, but varying your medium, focus, technique, inspiration can work wonders as well.

It's one of those things that is best honed through sheer trial and error, so keep at it. Intensive bursts over the span of a month or so can help a lot, in my experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6490144
Creativity comes from being interested in different things: ideas, art, life, etc. So much art feels derivative because artists tend to be influenced by the same pop culture (mostly anime and vidya nowadays). Be genuinely curious about different things and your art will be more interesting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6490144
Be a curious person.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Try this:

To someone who has never drawn a line,I would advise that phrase,and this simple excercise...on a drawing pad of good quality, scribble on a page lightly in pencil for a count of 1-2-3 and then look at the shapes and see what they suggest to you. Then in pen,draw over the shape,and add to it. This will help alleviate the WhuhTuhDruh symptoms of stupification and apathy. And I would also remind them that what they are doing is Exploring, don't take it seriously, have fun,and discover what you can do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473866
Never saw that drawing, but the torso looked blobby to me, and the belly looked rather concave because of the values you used. Also the hips seemed a bit iffy to me. Pic has the value shapes you used in red and blue is the implied form. The belly definition was just my personal preference. You can blur the abs and it wouldn't really matter. About the light, here's a tip, when you compare the rgb sliders of an unlit area and a lit one, and one of the sliders moves in the opposite direction of the rest, there's something strange going on. The exception is when the lit area is the shadow area of another light or when you're straight up changing hues. This is not a hard rule, but something to think about.

Cherrypicking some random drawings for acrylic stands which aren't even shots from the actual show really doesn't prove anything especially when even doing that you can't say anything but to back it up except "bro it's trash trust me". Onimai is pretty technically solid at a level of both direction and animation, and there's a lot of really good staff on it. It's really nothing like ""calarts style"", which is a term nobody on this site even fucking understands. It was coined by John K to refer to a Disney style he viewed as degrading through generations of interbred copying. Specifically he was talking about the style in stuff like The Iron Giant. And then people started using it to mean flat beanmouth shit which still isn't even close to Onimai's drawing style.

I will give you one thing, I know a nice anime friend who does have a very *structural* approach and I look up to him.
Nothing about rendering though although he does have a big knack for crosshatching (which also has to do with form).
I don't think an approach of structure is the best approach, rather shapes or perhaps the intention of the lines and overall gesture should create a pretty picture.
It's not a very feasible approach for character animation I think. It just has to look right and if shit looks wonky then you have to make it so that it doesn't look wonky.

And the knee bone that's called the patella, yeah, you just have to draw the leg bend nice and at the lines for the form on the patella (remember no render allowed, that's a big no-no)

As an artist whose tried both, I highly respect artists who can pull off bw. It's actually so much more difficult than colored, because there are so many abstractions and design choices you have to study up on to make it work. With color, it's much more representative of real life.

>>6482022
I'm not actually so sure color takes that much longer. If you look at most manga, there's a huge amount of hatching going on. A page could take 10 hours if a single person worked on it. I guess it depends on the art-style, though.

On top of that, bw comics are much harder to manage assistants on, because you have to create instructions and documents to get them to do what you envisioned. With coloring, you can just hire a colorist, whose sole responsibility is coloring

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Colour adds infinitely more room for fuckups for only a marginal gain, and in my opinion comics with very intricate colouring actually get tiresome to look at after a while. Black and white or simpler colour(like limited palettes or something like Blacksad or Tintin) are much better for the actual reading experience.
Sometimes colour can help salvage readability when the original art was sloppy with composition and values, like some of the worse panels in Jojo parts 5 and 6, but that's the best I can say about those coloured versions. They look putrid. In general it's less unpleasant to sit through mediocre BW, because mediocre colour like digital airbrush or garish webtoon shit lowers the art as a whole, just look at the butchered right version in picrel.
So to answer the question, I prefer BW or simple on grounds of how comfortable they are to read, since they're harder to fuck up and I prefer comics that prioritise the flow of the narrative over making good individual "illustrations"(Alex Ross is a good artist but his comics feel very awkward to me)
Colour can be good but it's a whole new dimension of complexity added on top and if rushed it's often too generic to add to the storytelling, and by necessity if it doesn't have anything of meaning to add to the whole it'll detract from it.

>>6482084
Limited colour is pretty good but there's something to be said for the harsh contrast of BW, maybe paired with some grey values. It's very captivating and a whole tradition in and of itself, even back from the days of oldtimey book illustrations, and I think it's one of the reasons japanese comics are so successful. It makes for very immersive reading, I suggest checking out the bit about colour and BW in McCloud's Understanding Comics. I think it ties into the whole bit at the start about cartoonier characters being closer to meaning and text than they are to literal representations, so BW leaves more room for imagination and thus emotional attachment from the reader. Colour is more flashy and eye-catching to the general public, but it's not like they're a very enduring audience and anyone familiar with comics will be receptive to BW unless they're some capeshit consoomer.

>>6482017
Monochrome.
Color actually impedes the physical reading experience, even though it improves the observational experience. Reading is supposed to be smooth, clear, and quick. Language evolves to be smooth clear and quick. You want to communicate with as much ease as possible, and so the more visual elements you add the more bogged down that communication becomes. Your eyes become lost in the colors even if they look pretty. I feel the same way about black and white comics that use too many greys and too much detail on every page. I consider the best comics to be the ones where you not only get completely immersed in the story, but you're also turning the pages quickly so you don't get a chance to break that immersion or think about anything else. You shouldn't have to pause the story in your head to think "wow how beautiful" unless it's deliberately there for the pacing. You should only linger on a page if that is what the story calls for, like to take in the scenery or gravity. Black and white keeps your eyes moving, undistracted, turning the pages, until you hit a beautiful two page spread with intricacies deliberately rendered to make you stop and look carefully. And whatever you're looking at there, would likely be important.
As for skill level in coloring I don't care. A comic artist is a comic artist. It's a separate skill from illustration. Learning to speak in sequential imagery is a skill of its own that even the most skillful colorist could fail at. All language, including the language of sequential imagery, should be simple and concise. Highly skilled highly rendered colorful illustrations aren't simple and concise, they're just pretty. What you don't include in your art is just as important as what you do include. Manga is popular because people like it. It's just that simple. And they like it because it trims all the fat and focuses on easy visual communication and smooth eye movement, while also making its limited black and white look pretty.

>>6460328
To understand the meaning of "Just Draw" one must first understand that the true definition of talent is the ability to learn how to do something well with little to no instruction.

Now that we have that definition out of the way, we can begin with why the "just draw" phenomenon exists and why some people are able to actually benefit from the "just draw" when others seem to find it to be a trap.

Once we understand the definition of talent, we can now see why the "just draw" phrase is thrown around as if it was the most enlightened advice ever given. It is not because it actually works for everyone but rather that it works for anyone who has an innate ability to draw--innate not meaning "born with" but rather a proclivity towards drawing that creates a natural ability to learn things.

In order for "just draw" to actually work, one must have talent in drawing. This talent will allow you to be able to draw for hours and learn from your work and mistakes without any instruction whatsoever--though instruction could never hurt. If one does not have talent in drawing, they must seek out help in order to improve or else they will stagnate as pointed out by this anon: >>6463757

Basically, if you don't have talent, learning to draw will much harder and even if you do end up attaining a certain level of skill, your art will never be as good as most of the worst works from artists that do have talent which is why you have to find a reason to actually pursue art. You have to have a purpose as to why you are pursuing it rather than just the blind ambition of being able to draw le cute animu grill.

The real question we need to ask here is that if you do not possess such talent, would you still continue to draw? That is the real question you need to ask yourself here. That will allow you to determine whether or not to continue or if you should just quit.

>>6471926
>The Process of Drawing
Here we go, I'll try to explain as best as I could.

The difference between being able to perform and being able to teach is based on the understanding on the process of that specific skill. Performers tend to not understand the process of being able to learn something and therefore are the worst teachers in that field. They tended to have received their skill by sheer mileage and have often taken decades to get to where they currently are. As they have not properly analyzed their approach and why they do certain things, they have an intuitive understanding of drawing which only helps them. Basically, performers cannot teach and can only perform. This is where you get the advice to "just draw" because performers tend to be the ones that actually take this advice seriously and tend to get good by sheer mileage rather than anything concrete that you can teach to anyone.

Teachers understand a skill at a much higher level than performers and while they may not be as good as the performers, they will often coach the performers regardless. Note how coaches in sports aren't usually better than the players on the team. (If they were, they'd be mentors not teachers or coaches.) A teacher must have a very high level of understanding of whatever skill they are pursuing as they have to properly explain each and every step--otherwise, they're wasting everyone's time.

For instance, if we were to bring this back to drawing, lets say a beginner creates a drawing. You notice that the drawing is shit but because you are a performer, you can't exactly explain why it is shit. You can say something like, "the forms are off" or the "perspective is off" but you can't really delve exactly as to why the drawing is really bad, much less provide useful resources to practice from.

The teacher will be able to hyper-analyze a drawing and know exactly what the issues are what that beginner to study.

Most people on here are performers, NOT teachers.

>>6472033
Chances are when someone is asking you how they can learn how to draw, especially on here where the entire board is literally dedicated to this one skill, that person has tried to draw and might've even tried to learn how to draw but because they are so new to drawing, they do not understand how to approach it.

Just Draw, to a beginner, implies that they just continue to draw their bad symbols over and over again until they eventually improve. It DOES NOT imply--as others have erroneously said--you objectively look at your drawings and analyze why they are bad. This is not something a beginner--especially those who started drawing late--will be able to do as they do not understand the process of drawing.

Because this is a board dedicated towards the critiquing of discussing of artwork, it was quite strange for me to discover that the only piece of advice that was thrown around was "just draw." When you pursue any other skill, you never hear anyone just say, "just play the piano" or "just sing" or "just code" etc. There are typically well defined fundamentals that even those who literally just started are going to be aware of such as playing the scales as a pianist or learning the absolute basics of coding--though coding is a bit arbitrary to be honest.

It wasn't until I started to draw a lot more that I realized that most people on here don't actually analyze what they are doing. They kind of treat it like a video game where they simply play and play and play the game until they maybe get good rather than sitting back and analyzing what strategies are the best, what their weak-spots are, and what is worth practicing. This isn't to say you focus too much on strategies, obviously there is a level of performance that must take place, but completely neglecting it for "just playing" or "just drawing" is quite ridiculous.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6460328
since learning takes a bunch of time, the best advice they could give you is trust the years of hard work and eventually you'll see the results.

to get good results, it would make sense to analyze your piece after you've gained enough symbol making abilities and think (not emotionally, constructively)

> "OK, this I lack perspective skills"

this is quite simple to fix, perspective is very tactical, with enough grids you will see where you made a mistake, fix it, remember, draw enough to train your muscle memory and you'll draw buildings in perspective in no time,
if your hand is witty enough you can doodle something abstract in perspective. But to that you need to think with more IQ points,
there are some people breaking down every type of perspective while giving basic overalls on it, then apply into your art

>I don't know how to draw circular, soft shapes

from drawing a lot your hand should get smooth lines quite easily, practice drawing a circle, then lines curving around it, find other shapes from pictures and whatnot, draw a bunch of lines to understand the form, soon instead of blockiness you'll get smoothiness

hate shading? look at how it's done in real life, look at 2 values, thern add a rim light, then maybe really soft shapes with a lighter value, make sure to think how shapes reflect light,
find videos of light traveling across the room, going far and close to the object

you're an artist, and artist observes more than normal people, and if you wanna be a master, you gotta put in some studying into it as well

but never forget this, if you love drawing, you better draw your hands off and "just draw", and we promise you'll get gut

or take things slow, just remember to have fun in it too

Stop being Afraid.

>>6471842
A lot of people don't have concrete ideas of what they want to draw, or even what they like a lot of the time. Sometimes this is due to a "copying is bad" mind poison, sometimes it's due to a false idea that to "be a master" means that drawing entirely from imagination is the skill to practice.

In general, though, it's that they haven't made a conscious effort to examine their own tastes to where they have anything to say. It can be a compartmentalization issue - happens with coomer artists a lot, where they filter everything "not sexy" into a different mental box and so put almost no new inspiration into their "sexy art box" on the daily.

It could also be a complete disconnect between what they like to consume and what they like to produce - for some, a motivation to create is because of a lack of met desires with what currently exists. In this case they need to examine LOTS of things to know what to "not" make, which by extension gives them the mental negative-space shape of what fits the criteria of what they DO want to make.

Finally, unrelated to the other two, some people really need ultra basic help. Proper posture/desk setup for maximum arm movement is what is missing when a lot of people don't get how to draw from your shoulder, for example. And "How to use a ruler to measure things while drawing" is another, since some people, again, fuck up their mental compartments and remove all other skills from the "drawing" box. The aforementioned inability to compare to reference accurately (along without understanding that tracing can be a tool to help) is another. These are all things that are even more basic than what people call "Fundamentals," they're the kind of shit that almost nobody teaches or talks about outside of an atelier or private instruction.

Most people outside of this hellhole that are parroting "just draw" are assuming that those they speak with are just suffering from a confidence issue like performance anxiety.

Pic rel

>>6477369
To expand on point 2 and 3:
Just because someone likes horror doesn't mean they want to draw horror. They may be consumed by loving horror, but want to draw say - something more like Hamtaro or Sanrio.

But if they absolutely can't bear interacting with those media, then they're in a tough spot. They need to really examine what they like in great detail. A structure that works is a venn diagram:

>What I can do as good as them (for beginners this will be mostly empty, this exercise is repeated yearly or every six months or so)
>What elements I want to copy from them
>What elements of theirs I don't want to incorporate into my work

So to continue the example, they may want to draw cute shit and use bold lines and huge eyes, but with some kind of "implied story threads" that are more like the cute, cozy energy found in drawings people do of POKEMON, not hamtaro or sanrio.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6478345
I used to have that fear and managed to turn it around. I just accepted w/e I was about to draw was going to be the worst drawing of my life, and realized that's a great thing, because if what I shit out is the worst I'll ever be, it means everything I make after it has to be better. I celebrated awful drawings, because I COULD tell they were mega shit, I could see obvious mistakes, and try to learn from them for w/e I tried next. The scariest thing (which I've yet to reach), is the point where you draw something, and are unable to see anything wrong with it. You see it often on this board, stubborn /beg/s posting deviantart OC tier trash and insisting nothing is wrong with it. If you know you suck, and what parts you suck at, you can take objectionable action.
The more you think about it, the more daunting it becomes, so just don't think and start filling pages, don't give those thoughts the time of day, spite them. When I finish a drawing, instead of focusing on the shit parts and being depressed, I'll go "hey, that hand didn't come out half bad, maybe I am improving" followed by "fuck you, fear of drawing, I finished another drawing, what the fuck you gonna do? huh? you still scared of drawing little bitch? lmao look at me I filled a page with confidence where you couldn't last year, and I'll do it again tomorrow". I take the same attitude towards shitters and crabs on this board. Every time I finish a drawing or study it's another victory against the faggots who tried to demoralize me and get me to quit. I've decided I'm gonna make it and that's that, anyone saying otherwise is wrong, even if it's my own subconscious. It's not even a question, therefore quitting is wrong, procrastinating is wrong, listening to doomers and AIfags is wrong, and every mark I'm putting down is proof of it.

Let me now interpret this rather glib phrase Just Draw :

To someone who has never drawn a line,I would advise that phrase,and this simple excercise...on a drawing pad of good quality, scribble on a page lightly in pencil for a count of 1-2-3 and then look at the shapes and see what they suggest to you. Then in pen,draw over the shape,and add to it. This will help alleviate the WhuhTuhDruh symptoms of stupification and apathy. And I would also remind them that what they are doing is Exploring, don't take it seriously, have fun,and discover what you can do.

>>6481616
Invest in some good quality drawing pads,and one pad of Bristol board. And,for now,black ballpoint pens,and a pencil.

Take the pad,and for a count of 1-2-3,scribble lightly with the pencil. Now see what the random shapes suggest to you. If this squiggle looks like a face use the pen to highlight those marks,and add details of your own. Feel free to draw upside down if the random shapes look promising. And,importantly, know that this is a way to awaken your imagination, and don't be disappointed with your first outings into art,even trying is to be applauded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483323
A lot of people don't actually have ideas all that often. It's not anxiety or perfectionism about making the drawing, it's that they sit down, don't know what to draw, and then do like >>6483191
Drawing random shapes is still useful, but there is an element of art where you have to actually try to examine your tastes and influences in detail.

A lot of people seem to think that artists just "have to make new and creative art from ideas in their heads" like they have to take a shit or it will build up in them like constipation. But that isn't the reality. You have to really self-examine what you like, why and what elements of those things you like, and what you don't.

References are good, but know what references to keep - SPECIFIC TO WHAT YOU WANNA DRAW - is hugely important. Not "saving every tutorial you find", not "saving a bunch of "royalty free model" shots. IF you want to draw mecha? Save mechanical images. Save vehicles, save electronics, save scifi things. Save manufactured objects. Or don't! If you wanna draw super robots instead, look at things like armor, focus on aesthetics you enjoy and so on.
You wanna draw cute girls? Well you first need to know what kinds of girls you find cute and then make an effort to save those.

To be a good artist requires knowing yourself, your tastes, and using that information to propel your work.
